presets.notes: Gold standard horizontal push. Flat angle activates both pec heads equally (~27% MVIC each). Standard grip width maximizes pec engagement.
Optimal angle for upper pec development (122-130% MVIC vs flat). Research shows 30Â° maximizes clavicular activation before deltoid dominance.
Anterior deltoid approaches pec activation levels. Lower pec drops to ~72% MVIC. Consider 30Â° for pure chest focus.
Highest sternal pec activation (100.4% MVIC). Reduced anterior deltoid involvement. 15-25Â° decline angle typical.
Narrow grip (shoulder width) increases triceps activation 10-25%. Slightly elevated clavicular head activation. Primary triceps builder.
Greater ROM than barbell allows deeper stretch. Higher stabilization demand. 57-86% higher biceps activation as stabilizer. Potentially superior for pec hypertrophy due to lengthened position.
Combines incline upper pec emphasis with dumbbell ROM advantages. Greater stretch in bottom position than barbell. Optimal at 30Â° angle.
Greater ROM than barbell decline. Sternal/costal fiber emphasis. Reduced anterior deltoid involvement.
Fixed path reduces stabilizer demand. Neutral grip may increase clavicular activation (~30% vs 25% MVIC with pronated). Safe for training to failure.
Same incline principles apply as free weights. Fixed path allows focus on prime movers. Good for isolating upper chest.
Similar PM activation to free weights. Medial deltoid ~50% lower activation due to guided path. Allows heavier loads and safer solo training.
Clavicular head significantly greater at 44Â° and 56Â° vs flat. More consistent path allows focus on target muscles.
Constant tension throughout ROM. Standing version requires significant core stabilization. Greater shoulder joint moment than bench press.
Low-to-high angle specifically targets clavicular fibers. Constant tension advantage over incline dumbbell press.
Gold standard vertical push. Standing requires ~20% greater core activation. 39% more triceps activation than dumbbell version. ~33% MVIC anterior deltoid.
Allows ~10% heavier loads than standing. ~25% less posterior deltoid, ~20% less triceps activation vs standing. Minimal core demand.
Leg drive allows ~30% more weight overhead. Lower isolated deltoid work. Significantly higher erector spinae and external oblique activation vs strict press.
HIGHEST deltoid activation of all press variations per research. ~15% greater anterior deltoid vs standing barbell. Greatest stability requirement. ~7% lower 1RM.
~11% greater anterior deltoid than seated barbell. ~8% lower activation vs standing DB. Balance of load capacity and activation.
29% greater anterior deltoid and 14% greater medial deltoid vs standard DB press. Rotation engages all three deltoid heads. Superior for shoulder hypertrophy.
All muscles show LOWER activation vs barbell (effect size 1.42-2.80). Allows heaviest absolute loads. Fixed path reduces stabilizer demand.
Angled press (~45Â° from vertical) between horizontal and vertical plane. Single-arm variation increases anti-rotation demand. Shoulder-friendly alternative.
Forward lean of 30-45Â° emphasizes pectoralis major.  Ring dip shows greatest peak pec activation. Bar dip ~25-35Â° forward lean typical.
Upright position (~10-15Â° lean) shifts emphasis to triceps.  Bench dip has smallest lean but highest shoulder extension ROM.  ~88% normalized triceps EMG.
Progressive overload increases all muscle activation proportionally. Six muscles show significantly greater activation on bar dip vs bench dip.
Counter-resistance allows moderation of load. Same recruitment patterns as bar dip at reduced intensity. Good for progression building.
66% pec activation vs bench press. Peak tension at stretched/bottom position. Minimal triceps. Superior for lengthened-position training (Maeo 2022).
Higher clavicular activation than flat. 69% pec activation vs bench. Optimal at 15-30Â° angle. Above 45Â° shoulders dominate.
93-94% pec activation vs bench press - no significant difference. Constant tension throughout ROM. High activation during crossover phase.
Upward arc specifically recruits clavicular fibers. Greater continuous tension than incline dumbbell fly. Trajectory mirrors upper pec fiber direction.
Downward arc specifically recruits costal/sternal fibers. Maintains tension at peak contraction unlike decline DB flies.
98% pec activation vs bench press - essentially interchangeable. 'Produces best motor-unit activation' per ACE. Constant tension, safe to failure.
~65% body weight load. Pec ~64% MVC, deltoid ~59% MVC, triceps ~74% MVC. Global EMG 38.2% MVIC. Foundational bodyweight push.
Significantly reduced load (~41-55% BW depending on height). Global EMG ~16% MVIC. Serratus anterior highest relative activation. Regression/rehab option.
~70-80% BW load. Shifts emphasis to upper pec and anterior deltoid, mimicking incline press. Increased activation across all muscles.
#1 MOST EFFECTIVE triceps exercise per ACE study. Significantly greater activation than wide-base for both triceps AND pectoralis major (p=0.005/0.026).
Wide grip increases sternocostal PM activation. Triceps activation decreases 10-20%. 1.5-2x biacromial width. Greater shoulder stress.
Limited ROM eliminates deep stretch. Upper-half ROM emphasizes triceps more than pectoralis. Lockout strength builder.
Greatest peak pec sEMG amplitude of all dip variations (p=0.002-0.008). Instability significantly increases stabilizer demand.
Isometric adduction emphasis. Constant pec contraction throughout. Light weight, high time under tension. Good for mind-muscle connection.
Fixed path eliminates stabilization demands. Medial deltoid activation 50% lower than free weights. Good for isolating chest with fatigue.
Upper pec targeting with machine stability. Allows higher volume work when stabilizers are fatigued.
Core activation reduced 60-70% vs standing. Back support allows greater load focus on shoulders. Good for strict shoulder work.
Highest deltoid activation of any pressing variant. 11-15% greater anterior deltoid activation than barbell. Independent arms require more stabilization.
Excellent shoulder isolation with back support. Maintains dumbbell benefits (ROM, independent arms) while reducing core demands.
Counterweight reduces effective bodyweight. Approximately 25-30% lower activation vs full bodyweight. Good progression tool.
CAUTION: Requires 101% maximal shoulder extension ROMâ€”higher anterior shoulder injury risk. Consider parallel bar dips as safer alternative.
Lower EMG activation in BOTH pec and triceps vs narrow/standard. Greater horizontal abduction but reduced ROM contributes to lower overall activation.
Olympic-style squat with bar on upper traps. Upright torso emphasizes quadriceps. Deep squats (below parallel) increase glute and adductor activation.
Powerlifting-style with bar on rear delts. Forward lean shifts emphasis to posterior chain. Typically allows heavier loads than high bar.
Most upright torso position maximizes quad emphasis. Front rack position limits load but reduces spinal stress. EMG shows highest rectus femoris activation of squat variations.
Beginner-friendly front-loaded squat. Counterbalance allows natural deep squat position. Limited by weight held.
Wide stance with toes pointed out increases adductor and gluteus medius activation. External rotation of sumo stance enhances glute recruitment.
Fixed path machine removes balance requirement. Lower erector spinae activation than free squats. Different foot placements shift emphasis between quads and glutes.
Fixed vertical path allows different foot positions. Reduced stabilizer activation compared to free barbell. Can place feet forward to increase glute emphasis.
Standard angled leg press. Greater quadriceps activation at deep knee flexion. High foot placement increases hip extension demand.
Seated horizontal position with less hip flexion than 45Â° version. Similar quad emphasis but reduced glute involvement due to body position.
Arc-based movement creates unique resistance profile. Maintains tension throughout range, particularly effective at stretched position for quadriceps.
Maximum quad stretch by leaning back while descending. Hip extension minimizes glute involvement. Rectus femoris highly emphasized due to hip extension position.
Full-body compound lift. Greater knee extension moment than sumo. Erector spinae highly stressed due to forward torso lean. Quadriceps significantly involved in floor initiation.
Wide stance reduces range of motion. More upright torso decreases spinal shear stress. Greater hip abductor and adductor demands than conventional.
Center of mass aligned with body reduces lumbar stress. More quad-dominant than conventional due to more upright position. Neutral grip reduces bicep injury risk.
Hip hinge with slight knee bend emphasizes hamstrings at long muscle lengths. Superior hamstring stretch compared to conventional deadlift. Key exercise for hamstring hypertrophy.
Dumbbells allow natural arm path and slightly greater range of motion. Lower erector stress than barbell version due to typically lighter loads.
Single-leg stance dramatically increases gluteus medius demand for pelvic stability. Excellent for addressing bilateral asymmetries. Balance component limits load.
Minimal knee flexion maximizes hamstring stretch. Higher erector spinae activation than RDL. Step-RDL (deficit) further increases glute and hamstring activation.
Standing on platform increases range of motion. Research shows step-RDL produces greater glute and semitendinosus activation than standard RDL or stiff-leg.

Peak glute activation occurs at full hip extension where glutes are strongest. Knee flexion places hamstrings in active insufficiency, forcing greater glute contribution. EMG shows 2x greater glute activation than squat.
Unilateral version increases gluteus medius demand significantly. Addresses strength asymmetries. Can progress to weighted version.
Floor-based version with reduced range compared to hip thrust. Excellent activation exercise and warm-up. Lower intensity than elevated hip thrust.
Isolated hip extension with supported position. Unilateral execution addresses asymmetries. Machine stabilization allows focus on mind-muscle connection.
Dynamic lunge variation with continuous forward motion. High metabolic demand. EMG shows high VL and VM activation. Greater glute medius demand for stability during transition.
Stepping backward shifts more emphasis to front leg glutes and hamstrings. More knee-friendly than forward lunge as shear forces are reduced. Better for beginners.
Fixed foot position allows heavier loading than walking variation. Can emphasize quads (upright) or glutes (forward lean) based on torso position.
Rear foot elevation increases range of motion and front leg demand. Research shows higher hamstring:quad ratio than back squat. Greater hip moment demand suggests hip-dominant pattern.
Barbell version allows heavier loading but requires more stability. Balance demands increase core activation. Can be done in Smith machine for stability.
Functional movement pattern. Higher step increases hip flexion and glute demand. Minimize push-off from trailing leg for maximal lead leg emphasis.
Frontal plane movement increases gluteus medius and adductor demand. Excellent for hip stability development. Lower quad activation than forward step-up.

Isolated knee extension. Rectus femoris highly activated due to shortened hip position. Research shows leg extension produces superior rectus femoris growth vs squats. Effective for quad hypertrophy when combined with compound movements.
Unilateral execution addresses strength imbalances. Same muscle activation pattern as bilateral. Useful for post-injury rehabilitation.

Hip-extended position places hamstrings in shortened state. Research shows slightly greater biceps femoris than semitendinosus activation. Less overall hypertrophy than seated curl due to shorter muscle length.

Hip flexion places biarticular hamstrings in lengthened position. Research shows 14% vs 9% whole hamstring hypertrophy compared to lying curl. Superior for biceps femoris long head, semitendinosus, and semimembranosus growth.

High-intensity eccentric hamstring exercise. Semitendinosus slightly more activated than biceps femoris. Peak EMG occurs in 60-40Â° knee flexion range. Essential for hamstring injury prevention in athletes.
Combines hip extension and knee flexion. Both hamstring heads highly activated. More glute involvement than pure knee flexion exercises due to hip movement component.
Isolated hip abduction targets gluteus medius. Seated position with hip flexion may increase tensor fasciae latae contribution. Useful for hip stability development.
Standing position with hip extended may reduce TFL contribution compared to seated. Unilateral execution addresses asymmetries. Can be done lying for different angle.
Isolated hip adduction. Adductor magnus, longus, and brevis all activated. Useful for addressing adductor weakness and injury prevention.

Extended knee position maximizes gastrocnemius stretch and activation. Research shows standing calf raise produces greater overall triceps surae hypertrophy than seated. Most effective for gastrocnemius development.
Smith machine provides stability for straight-leg calf work. Same muscle activation as dedicated machine. Requires block or step for range of motion.
Single-leg execution allows bodyweight plus dumbbell loading. Addresses bilateral asymmetries. Requires balance - can hold support for stability.

Bent knee position places gastrocnemius in active insufficiency, isolating soleus. Research shows equal soleus hypertrophy to standing but minimal gastrocnemius growth. Important for complete calf development.
Hip flexion creates hamstring-gastrocnemius interaction, maintaining tension. Similar activation to standing calf raise with slightly different feel. Allows heavy loading.
Hip flexion with straight knees stretches gastrocnemius over both joints simultaneously. Classic bodybuilding exercise. Maximizes gastrocnemius stretch.
Hip extension focused movement despite name. Can emphasize glutes by squeezing at top or spinal erectors with slight lumbar flexion/extension. Pad position affects muscle emphasis.
Legs move while torso stays fixed. Provides spinal decompression effect. Greater glute emphasis than traditional back extension. Excellent for posterior chain development.
Hip hinge with barbell on back. High erector spinae demand due to long moment arm. Hamstring activation similar to RDL. Requires careful load progression.
Advanced single-leg squat requiring full depth. High gluteus medius demand for stability. Rectus femoris highly activated as hip flexor for non-stance leg.
Load applied at hips eliminates spinal compression. Pure lower body exercise - no erector spinae demand. Excellent for high-volume leg training or those with back issues.
Angled barbell path creates natural front-loaded position. Allows deep squat with upright torso. Good progression between goblet and barbell front squat.
Combines hip extension and knee flexion with instability challenge. Lower intensity than machine curl but includes hip extension component. Good for home/travel workouts.
Supine position with feet on sliders. Progressive exercise from bridge position. High-intensity classification in EMG research. Excellent minimal-equipment hamstring exercise.
Ballistic hip hinge. Research shows higher semitendinosus than biceps femoris activation. Power development for hip extensors. Low-intensity EMG classification but high metabolic demand.
Cable hip hinge with continuous tension. Horizontal force vector similar to hip thrust at lockout. Good hip hinge teaching tool and glute builder.
Unilateral leg press addresses strength asymmetries. Increased stabilization demand compared to bilateral. Can use heavier relative loads than free-weight unilateral exercises.
Isometric quad exercise. Back support eliminates spinal loading. Endurance-focused training. Thigh parallel position provides highest quadriceps activation.
Basic staggered stance squat pattern. Less hip moment demand than Bulgarian split squat. Good precursor to more advanced split stance exercises.
Cross-body step increases gluteus medius demand and adductor stretch. Multi-planar movement pattern. Increased hip stability challenge.
Wide stance (>1.5x shoulder width) increases glute max by 18-60% and adductor activation significantly. Allows greater hip external rotation and depth.
Kettlebell handle position increases forearm/grip demands compared to dumbbell version. Excellent for warm-ups and technique work.

Standard foot position (mid-platform, shoulder-width). Squats generate greater quad and hamstring activation, but leg press allows safe high-volume training. Peak quad activation at 90Â° knee flexion.
High foot position shifts emphasis to hip extension, significantly increasing gluteus maximus activation while reducing knee flexion demands.
Low foot position emphasizes rectus femoris and vastus lateralis with greater knee extension demands. Maximum quad stimulus from leg press.
Wide stance increases hamstring and adductor activation without significantly affecting quadriceps. Good for inner thigh emphasis.
Lumbar erector spinae reaches 142-158% MVICâ€”primarily a back exercise despite hamstring stretch. Greater stretch-mediated hamstring stimulus than lying curls. Use moderate loads.
Adding load approaches hip thrust effectiveness. Floor contact provides stable spine position. Can use barbell, dumbbell, or plate for loading.
54-58% MVIC gluteus maximus. Dynamic movement increases metabolic demand vs stationary. Forward lean increases glute/posterior chain emphasis. Excellent for athletic development.
Greater glute and posterior chain emphasis than forward lunge. Reduced knee stress as front shin stays more vertical. Better for hip-dominant pattern training.
Barbell allows heavier loading than dumbbells. Back rack position increases erector spinae demands. Front rack version shifts to quad emphasis.
70% MVIC gluteus maximusâ€”classified as 'very high' activation. Stationary position allows focus on technique. Lower metabolic demand than walking lunges.

Significantly higher gluteus medius and hamstring activation than bilateral squats. Hip-dominant unilateral exercise. Rear foot elevation increases hip ROM and stretch at depth. Trunk flexion increases glute/hamstring emphasis.
Barbell allows heavier loading. Increased erector spinae and core demands vs dumbbell version. Back rack position standard; front rack shifts quad emphasis.
Highest gluteus maximus activation of tested exercises at 169% MVIC (Krause Neto 2020). Stretched position under load. Concentric-dominant. Higher box = greater glute activation.
Barbell loading allows heavier weights but requires more balance. Increased erector spinae and core demands. Maintain controlled descent.

Maximum quad isolation. Rectus femoris activation limited due to hip-flexed (seated) position. Peak activation at 90Â° knee flexion, decreases toward extension. Emphasize stretched/initial ROM for hypertrophy (Pedrosa 2022).
Addresses bilateral quad imbalances. Slight increase in stabilizer demands. Same ROM principles applyâ€”emphasize stretched position for hypertrophy.
81% MVIC gluteus mediusâ€”highest of therapeutic exercises. Internal rotation of hip during movement increases activation further. Excellent for rehabilitation and glute med activation.
More challenging than 45Â° version with peak torque in upper portion. Lower hamstring activation due to knee position on GHD. Greater emphasis on glutes and erectors.
Pronated wide grip maximizes teres major involvement. Similar lat activation to standard grip per Andersen 2014. Full ROM essential - emphasize stretch at bottom.
sources: Youdas et al. 2010 J Strength Cond Res

presets.notes: 117-130% MVIC lat activation. Highest lat EMG among back exercises per Edelburg 2017. Lower traps significantly more active than chin-ups.
sources: Youdas et al. 2010 J Strength Cond Res 24(12):3404-3414

presets.notes: Supinated grip significantly increases biceps brachii activation (78-96% MVIC). Similar lat activation to pull-ups but greater bicep and pec involvement.
sources: Youdas et al. 2010 J Strength Cond Res

presets.notes: Lowest middle trapezius activation (37% peak MVIC) per Dickie 2017. Neutral grip emphasizes brachialis and brachioradialis. Comfortable wrist position.
sources: Dickie et al. 2017 J Electromyogr Kinesiol 32:30-36

presets.notes: Signorile 2002: Wide anterior grip produces greatest LD and teres major activation. Pronated grip elicits significantly greater LD than supinated per Lusk 2010.
sources: Signorile et al. 2002 J Strength Cond Res 16(4):539-546

presets.notes: Similar lat activation to wide grip per Andersen 2014. Allows heavier loads (6RM: 80.3kg vs 77.3kg wide). Tendency for higher biceps activation.
sources: Andersen et al. 2014 J Strength Cond Res 28(4):1135-1142

presets.notes: V-bar shows similar LD activation to front-of-neck wide grip per Sperandei 2009. Comfortable wrist position for high volume training.
sources: Sperandei et al. 2009 J Strength Cond Res 23(7):2033-2038

presets.notes: Significantly lower LD activation than pronated grip per Lusk 2010. Greater biceps emphasis. Best for combined back/biceps training.
sources: Lusk et al. 2010 J Strength Cond Res 24(7):1895-1900

presets.notes: Unilateral work increases per-side activation and core anti-rotation demand. Excellent for addressing asymmetries. 59-63% greater oblique activation vs bilateral.
sources: Saeterbakken et al. 2015 Int J Sports Med

presets.notes: 53.4% MVIC lat (up phase), 42.5% MVIC erector spinae. Second-best exercise for lower traps after I-Y-T raises per Edelburg 2017. Highest spine compression: 3576N.
sources: Fenwick et al. 2009 J Strength Cond Res 23(2):350-358

presets.notes: Supinated grip increases biceps brachii involvement significantly. Allows pulling bar closer to body. Popular variation for combined back/biceps emphasis.
Parallel torso emphasizes horizontal abduction plane - greater mid/lower trap and rhomboid involvement. Bar returns to floor each rep. Symmetrical erector activation.
sources: Fenwick et al. 2009 J Strength Cond Res 23(2):350-358

presets.notes: Chest support eliminates erector spinae demand - allows greater focus on target muscles. Lower spine loads per Garcia-Jaen 2021. Optimal for lat hypertrophy with reduced fatigue.
sources: Garcia-Jaen et al. 2021 J Phys Ed Sport

presets.notes: 91 mean peak lat activation per Contreras EMG. Pulling to hip emphasizes lower lats; pulling to ribcage emphasizes upper back. Greater anti-rotation demand.
Shoulder abduction position increases posterior deltoid and mid trap activation per Garcia-Jaen 2021. 45Â° incline bench provides optimal chest support.
sources: Garcia-Jaen et al. 2021 J Phys Ed Sport

presets.notes: Highest mid-back activation of all exercises tested per Contreras 2010. Neutral grip allows natural wrist position. Significant erector spinae demand.
Highest middle trap/rhomboid activation vs lat pulldown per Lehman 2004. 0Â° shoulder abduction maximizes lat involvement per Vasconcelos 2023.
sources: Vasconcelos et al. 2023 Int J Strength Cond

presets.notes: 90Â° shoulder abduction dramatically increases upper trap (130-138% MVIC), mid trap, and rear delt while DECREASING lat activation by ~50% per Vasconcelos 2023.
sources: Vasconcelos et al. 2023 Int J Strength Cond

presets.notes: Balanced activation between lats and upper back. Neutral grip comfortable for high volume. No significant difference between grip types for lat activation per Lehman 2004.
Creates greatest torsional challenge per Fenwick 2009. Internal oblique activation 20.8% MVIC vs 12-13.3% in bilateral rows. Excellent for anti-rotation training.
sources: Fenwick et al. 2009 J Strength Cond Res

presets.notes: High anchor promotes external rotation - increases infraspinatus (62% MVIC) and teres minor (67% MVIC) per Reinold 2004. Essential for shoulder health and posture.
sources: Reinold et al. 2004 J Orthop Sports Phys Ther 34(7):385-394

presets.notes: Erector spinae 60-63% of free-weight row activation per Saeterbakken 2015. Highest lat:biceps ratio with constant tension. Excellent for controlled hypertrophy work.
sources: Saeterbakken et al. 2015 Int J Sports Med 36:900-905

presets.notes: Chest pad eliminates erector spinae demand. Fixed path ensures consistent loading. Independent arms allow addressing imbalances.
sources: Biomechanical analysis based on Fenwick et al. 2009

presets.notes: 64.8% MVIC lat activation (up phase) - highest of all row variations per Fenwick 2009. Upper erector 90.9% MVIC. Spine compression 35% lower than bent-over row.
sources: Fenwick et al. 2009 J Strength Cond Res 23(2):350-358

presets.notes: Marchetti & Uchida 2011: Pec major dominates - lat IEMG only ~10% of pec major. NOT an effective lat exercise despite gym lore. Provides stretch stimulus for triceps long head.
Significantly higher lat activation than dumbbell pullover per Muyor 2022 (~18% MVIC). Eliminates bicep involvement - superior lat isolation. Grip width doesn't affect activation.
69% MVIC upper trapezius per Andersen 2012. Allows heaviest loading for progressive overload. Activates levator scapulae substantially per De Mey 2016.
sources: Andersen et al. 2012 J Strength Cond Res 26(9):2408-2417

presets.notes: Greater ROM than barbell shrugs - potentially superior activation per 2018 EMG study. Better mind-muscle connection. Addresses unilateral imbalances.
Most natural hand position (neutral grip). Allows heaviest loads of all shrug variations. Side weight position reduces forward pull - better posture maintenance.
sources: Ekstrom et al. 2003 J Orthop Sports Phys Ther 33:247-258

presets.notes: Highest posterior deltoid activation among all rear delt exercises per Schoenfeld 2013. Neutral grip significantly increases rear delt and infraspinatus (p=0.002) vs pronated.
sources: Schoenfeld et al. 2013 J Strength Cond Res 27(10):2644-2649

presets.notes: Prone horizontal abduction at 100Â° with external rotation: 88% MVIC posterior deltoid per Reinold 2004. 45Â° arm angle from body aligns with rear delt fiber direction.
sources: Reinold et al. 2004 J Orthop Sports Phys Ther

presets.notes: High-to-low 45Â° angle matches rear delt fiber orientation. Constant tension throughout ROM advantageous vs dumbbells. Top performer for rear delts in EMG testing.
Rope allows external rotation at end of pull - increases rotator cuff involvement. Natural grip position reduces wrist strain. Good hybrid between row and face pull.
Pronated grip emphasizes lat stretch. Unique arc of motion from landmine setup. High anti-rotation demand. Created by John Meadows for lat-focused rowing.
Close neutral grip allows heavy loading with natural wrist position. Standing version has high erector demand; chest-supported version reduces spinal load.
Incline position lengthens biceps at shoulder - emphasizes stretch position for superior hypertrophy per Maeo 2022 lengthened training research.
Arm behind body maximally lengthens biceps. Emphasizes stretched position - superior for hypertrophy per lengthened training research (Pedrosa 2023).
sources: Pedrosa et al. 2023 Eur J Sport Sci

presets.notes: Neutral grip: -12% biceps brachii vs supinated per Coratella 2023. Emphasizes brachialis and brachioradialis. Best for overall arm thickness.
Pronated grip: -19% biceps brachii vs supinated (p less than 0.001, ES: 2.60) per Coratella 2023. Maximizes brachialis and forearm involvement.
Bench support eliminates momentum. Emphasizes short head of biceps. Arm position in front of body creates shortened position - pair with incline curls for full development.
Supinated grip maximizes biceps brachii activation. Allows heaviest loading for biceps. Brachioradialis also highly active with supinated grip per Coratella 2023.
ACE study found highest biceps activation among curl variations. Elbow braced against thigh eliminates momentum. Excellent for mind-muscle connection.
Constant tension throughout ROM - no dead spot at top unlike dumbbell curls. Low pulley position provides resistance curve favoring bottom stretch position.
Arms abducted position creates unique resistance angle. Peak contraction emphasis. Popular for biceps peak development and posing practice.
~9% LOWER lat activation than pronated grip (significant, p<0.05). Pronated grip superior for pure lat targeting. Use when biceps emphasis desired.
53-82% MVIC lat activation, 42-43% MVIC erector spinae. Highest lumbar spine load (~3576N compression) among rows. Pull to lower chest for lat emphasis, higher for mid-back.
Supinated grip significantly increases biceps activation. More upright torso (45°) reduces lumbar load vs parallel position. Elbows tucked, bar pulled to lower chest. Named after Dorian Yates.
Erector spinae 34% LOWER, multifidus 27-30% LOWER, obliques 43-50% LOWER than free-weight rows. Target muscle activation maintained. Iso-lateral arms allow unilateral work. Eliminates momentum.

High pulling angle shifts emphasis to upper traps, rear delts, and upper lat fibers. Chest support eliminates spinal loading. Excellent for upper back thickness. Often performed with external rotation at peak contraction.

Low pulling angle emphasizes lower lat fibers and teres major. Greater shoulder extension pattern. Excellent for lat width development. Chest support allows heavier loading. Full stretch at start position.

Chest-supported on steep incline (70-80°). Row with elbows flared at 45-60°. Emphasizes mid-back over lats compared to standard chest-supported row. Named after Dr. Eric Helms. Eliminates momentum completely.

Heavy single-arm row with controlled body english. Named after Matt Kroczaleski. High reps (15-25) with maximum weight. Allows slight torso rotation and leg drive. Grip often limiting factor—great forearm builder. More trap involvement due to shrugging action.

Arthur Jones designed Nautilus pullover specifically for lat isolation. Constant resistance curve throughout ROM. Deep stretch at top—excellent for stretch-mediated hypertrophy. Elbows push pads rather than hands pulling. Superior lat targeting to dumbbell pullover.

Bar position behind body shifts emphasis slightly to middle trap and posterior shoulder. Requires more shoulder external rotation. Smith machine often preferred for guided bar path. Limited ROM compared to front barbell.

Arms abducted 30° showed SIGNIFICANTLY higher activation for BOTH upper AND lower trapezius compared to standard shrug (p<0.05). Only shrug variation to meaningfully target lower traps. Superior for comprehensive trap development. Recommended for shoulder health.

SIGNIFICANTLY greater posterior deltoid activation (p=0.001) vs seated row, inclined pulldown. NEUTRAL GRIP significantly increases posterior deltoid AND infraspinatus activation vs pronated (p=0.046 and p=0.002). Best machine for isolated rear delt work.

Chest supported on incline bench eliminates momentum and body english. Allows pure rear delt isolation. Gravity provides resistance throughout ROM. 30-45° incline typical. Excellent for mind-muscle connection.

Unilateral work allows focus on each side independently. Can achieve greater ROM and stretch. Slight anti-rotation demand. Standing facing cable stack, arm crosses body at start for maximum stretch. Addresses asymmetries.

Hybrid between row and rear delt fly. Lying face down on incline bench. Elbows flared at 60-90° during pull. Greater rhomboid and mid-trap involvement than pure isolation fly. Allows heavier loading than isolation movements.

144% mean, 252% peak rear delt activation—exceeding ALL isolation rear delt raises tested including cable face pulls. Increasing resistance at end range maximally loads shortened position. Excellent for warm-up and shoulder health.

Cable set at face height with wide pronated grip. Pull toward face with elbows high. Combination of face pull and wide row mechanics. Excellent for upper back thickness and rear delt. External rotation at end increases rotator cuff involvement.

Partial deadlift from knee height or above. Heavy loading for upper back and traps. Isometric back contraction at lockout. Grip often limiting factor. Overloads lockout position of deadlift. Less hamstring/glute involvement than full deadlift.
Foundational biceps exercise. Supinated grip maximizes biceps brachii activation. Straight bar forces full supination throughout ROM.
Semi-supinated grip reduces wrist strain. Slightly higher brachioradialis activation than straight bar due to grip angle.
Allows natural supination through ROM. Independent arms address bilateral imbalances. Slightly lower activation than barbell due to stabilization demands.
Unilateral execution allows slight core anti-rotation demand. Permits full focus on each arm independently.
Neutral grip shifts emphasis to brachialis and brachioradialis. Excellent for overall arm thickness. Reduces biceps brachii by ~12% vs supinated.
Shoulder extension stretches biceps long head. Kassiano 2025 found greater proximal biceps growth vs preacher curls. Key exercise for stretch-mediated hypertrophy.
Highest biceps EMG activation in ACE study (97% MVIC). Elbow bracing eliminates momentum. Peak contraction focus.
Shoulder flexion shortens biceps. EMG highest in initial ROM only. Kassiano 2025 found greater distal biceps growth. Emphasize stretched position for best results.
Unilateral version allows focus on each arm. Same shortened position limitations as barbell variant. Training initial ROM produces greater adaptations.
Fixed path reduces stabilization demands. Cam mechanism may provide better resistance curve than free weight version.
Constant tension throughout ROM. 80% MVIC in ACE study. Maintains resistance at peak contraction where dumbbells lose tension.
Combines neutral grip benefits with constant cable tension. Excellent brachialis and forearm developer.
67% combined MVIC. Shoulder-neutral position shortens long head, reducing its contribution. Lateral head shows highest activation.
Neutral grip may be more comfortable than straight bar. Similar activation profile to straight bar pushdown.
74% combined MVIC - outperforms bar variations by ~7%. Allows external rotation at lockout for greater lateral head engagement.

CRITICAL: Maeo 2023 showed 1.5Ã— greater long head hypertrophy than pushdowns despite 34-39% lighter loads. Shoulder flexion stretches biarticular long head. Priority exercise for triceps development.
Unilateral version adds anti-lateral flexion demand. Same stretch-mediated benefits as bilateral overhead work.
Both hands hold one dumbbell overhead. Seated position provides stability for heavier loads. Superior long head stretch.
62% combined MVIC. Partial long head stretch if arms angled behind head. Lower bar behind head rather than to forehead for greater stretch.
Most common skull crusher variation. EZ bar reduces wrist strain vs straight bar. Same activation profile.
Neutral grip reduces elbow stress. Independent arms allow natural movement path. Similar activation to barbell variant.
87% MVIC - second highest in ACE study. Often dismissed but highly effective. Shoulder extension position stretches long head. Light weights required for proper form.
62% triceps MVIC - compound movement. Nearly equal activation across all three heads. Better for pressing strength than triceps-specific hypertrophy.
55% lateral deltoid MVIC with neutral grip. Coratella 2020 found neutral grip optimal - internal rotation increases trap involvement. Larsen 2024 showed equivalent hypertrophy to cables.
Constant tension throughout ROM. 8-week study showed equivalent hypertrophy to dumbbells (3.3-4.6% thickness increase). Different resistance curve, same results.
Fixed path reduces synergist involvement. Highest lateral deltoid isolation. Useful for pre-exhaust or when fatigued.
51.6% anterior deltoid MVIC with pronated grip vs 43.4% neutral. Significant upper pec synergist activation. Often redundant if pressing volume is adequate.
Constant tension through full ROM. Same activation profile as dumbbell variant. Cable maintains resistance at top where dumbbells lose tension.
Neutral grip reduces anterior deltoid slightly vs pronated. Grip challenge may limit deltoid focus. Wide hand position provides stability.
54-68% rectus abdominis MVIC. Upper RA shows slightly higher activation than lower (ratio 1.25). Foundational core exercise.
Allows progressive overload with external resistance. Marginally higher activation than bodyweight. Focus on spinal flexion, not hip flexion.
Fixed path isolates spinal flexion. Similar activation to cable crunch when intensity matched. Useful for beginners learning movement pattern.
31-47% upper RA, 38-56% lower RA MVIC. Significant hip flexor involvement. Less rectus abdominis activation than crunch due to hip flexor contribution.
Higher activation than flat sit-up due to increased resistance. Greater hip flexor demand as well. Can hold weight for progressive overload.
60-80% MVIC. Significant hip flexor involvement below 45Â° flexion. Cue posterior pelvic tilt to maximize rectus abdominis. Grip often limiting factor.
212% relative activation in ACE study - ranked #2 for rectus abdominis. Back support reduces hip flexor dominance vs hanging. Elbow support eliminates grip limitation.
Lower rectus abdominis activation than hanging or captain's chair. Higher hip flexor demand without spine support. Press lower back into floor to increase ab engagement.
Bent knees reduce hip flexor lever arm, increasing relative rectus abdominis contribution. Good progression to straight leg raises. Focus on curling pelvis up.
External oblique dominant due to gravity-assisted downward pull. Diagonal muscle activation pattern. Trains rotation with resistance through full ROM.
Greater internal oblique demand for anti-gravity initiation. More rectus abdominis involvement than high-to-low. Both directions train diagonal pattern effectively.
45-60% external oblique MVIC, 40-55% internal oblique. V-sit position maintains rectus abdominis tension. Can add weight or medicine ball for progression.
Anti-rotation exercise - resists rotation rather than producing it. Sustained isometric co-contraction. Lower peak activation but superior time under tension with lower spinal load.
30-45% rectus abdominis MVIC baseline. Anti-extension exercise - resists spinal extension from gravity. Time under tension builds endurance. Progress with longer holds or added weight.
HIGHEST oblique activation: 107% MVIC internal oblique (JOSPM 2020). Bottom-side oblique dramatically more activated than top. Anti-lateral flexion exercise.
63% upper RA, 53% lower RA MVIC kneeling. Among highest rectus abdominis activating exercises. Standing version approaches 100% MVIC. Lat involvement for shoulder extension.
~74% MVIC flexor carpi radialis. Isolates wrist flexor compartment. Forearm supported on bench or thighs. Small ROM, controlled movement.
~68% brachioradialis MVIC. Targets wrist extensors. Lighter weight than wrist curls - extensors are weaker. Important for grip balance and elbow health.

Locomotion significantly increases activation vs static holds (p<0.0001). Longissimus 16.4%, external oblique 14.2%, rectus abdominis 10.7% MVIC. Unilateral (suitcase) increases contralateral oblique to 33%.
